abstract.p: Jonathan Fox, artistic director of Two River Theater Company in Manasquan, NJ, is staging revival of Moss Hart play Light Up the Sky (S)

block.p: Some theatergoers prefer Fats Waller or Jacques Brel retreads, or a Sigmund Romberg operetta. Others may long for the ''urbanity and wit of the great comedies of the 40's and the love of theater lore that doesn't exist today.''
Those are the words of Jonathan Fox, artistic director of Two River Theater Company in Manasquan.

Some theatergoers prefer Fats Waller or Jacques Brel retreads, or a Sigmund Romberg operetta. Others may long for the ''urbanity and wit of the great comedies of the 40's and the love of theater lore that doesn't exist today.''
Those are the words of Jonathan Fox, artistic director of Two River Theater Company in Manasquan.

It is for those devotees of theater esoterica, glamour and gossip -- don't forget malice -- that Mr. Fox is staging Moss Hart's ''Light Up the Sky,'' which runs through May 21. The play is about a play, Broadway bound. All the trapppings of opening night in Boston are acted out: the star's fits; the producer's, director's and playwright's feuds, and everybody else's flare ups.

''Light Up the Sky'' evokes a golden age when Broadway represented brand new plays and musicals, not just revivals. Hart's play opened in 1948, just before ''Kiss Me, Kate,'' ''Death of a Salesman'' and ''South Pacific.''
